title: A collider example in a medical context
text: Luckily, data includes timing measurements. know adjusting factors measured prior exposure (.e., want adjust proteinuria baseline follow-). Let’s look time varying dataset: Let’s suppose still erroneously think proteinuria confounder, carefully adjust baseline. Let’s begin examining balance. still observe positive relationship greater rule thumb (|0.1|). Now let’s create propensity score weights. can examine distribution weights:  can examine weighted correlation assess balance balance incorporating propensity score weight. Great! acheived balance (.e., weighted correlation less rule thumb, |0.1|). Now assessed balance, let’s fit outcome model estimate average treatment effect sodium intake systolic blood pressure. Note careful use follow-measurement outcome. wonderful! Even though erroneously adjusted proteinuria (actually confounder!), since baseline measurement, longer induced collider bias.
code: causal_collider_time ## # A tibble: 100 × 6 ##    exposure_baseline outcome_baseline covariate_baseline exposure_followup ##                <dbl>            <dbl>              <dbl>             <dbl> ##  1          -1.43              0.287             -0.0963          -1.53    ##  2           0.0593           -0.978             -1.11            -0.278   ##  3           0.370             0.348              0.647           -0.00464 ##  4           0.00471           0.851              0.755           -0.806   ##  5           0.340             1.94               1.19            -0.276   ##  6          -3.61             -0.235             -0.588           -5.29    ##  7           1.44             -0.827             -1.13             1.52    ##  8           1.02             -0.0410             0.689            1.12    ##  9          -2.43             -2.10              -1.49            -3.94    ## 10          -1.26             -2.41              -2.78            -0.442   ## # ℹ 90 more rows ## # ℹ 2 more variables: outcome_followup <dbl>, covariate_followup <dbl> causal_collider_time |>   summarise(cor(exposure_baseline, covariate_baseline)) ## # A tibble: 1 × 1 ##   `cor(exposure_baseline, covariate_baseline)` ##                                          <dbl> ## 1                                        0.324 denominator_model <- lm(   exposure_baseline ~ covariate_baseline,    data = causal_collider_time )  denominators <- causal_collider_time %>%    mutate(     propensity_score = predict(denominator_model),     denominator = dnorm(       exposure_baseline,        propensity_score,        sigma(denominator_model)     )) %>%    pull(denominator)   numerator_model <- lm(   exposure_baseline ~ 1,    data = causal_collider_time )  numerators <- causal_collider_time %>%    mutate(     mean_exposure = predict(numerator_model),     numerator = dnorm(       exposure_baseline,        mean_exposure,        sigma(numerator_model)     )) %>%    pull(numerator)   causal_collider_wts <- causal_collider_time %>%    mutate(swts = numerators / denominators) ggplot(causal_collider_wts, aes(x = swts)) +    geom_histogram(bins = 30) causal_collider_wts |>   summarise(     exposure_w = sum(swts * exposure_baseline) / sum(swts),     covariate_w = sum(swts * covariate_baseline) / sum(swts),     numerator = sum(swts * (exposure_baseline - exposure_w) * (covariate_baseline - covariate_w)),     denom = sqrt(sum(swts * (exposure_baseline - exposure_w)^2) * sum(swts * (covariate_baseline - covariate_w)^2)),     weighted_cor = numerator/denom   ) |>   select(weighted_cor) ## # A tibble: 1 × 1 ##   weighted_cor ##          <dbl> ## 1       0.0476 lm(outcome_followup ~ exposure_baseline, data = causal_collider_wts, weight = swts) ##  ## Call: ## lm(formula = outcome_followup ~ exposure_baseline, data = causal_collider_wts,  ##     weights = swts) ##  ## Coefficients: ##       (Intercept)  exposure_baseline   ##          -0.07298            1.03421

title: Datasets to Help Teach Statistics
text: Authors: Lucy D’Agostino McGowanLicense: MIT quartets package collection datasets aimed help data analysis practitioners students learn key statistical insights hands-manner. contains: Anscombe’s Quartet Causal Quartet Datasaurus Dozen Interaction Triptych Rashomon Quartet Gelman Variation Heterogeneity Causal Quartets

title: Datasets to Help Teach Statistics
text: can install development version quartets like :

title: Datasets to Help Teach Statistics
text: goal anscombe_quartet data set help drive home point visualizing data important. Francis Anscombe generated four datasets demonstrate statistical summary measures alone capture full relationship two variables (, x y). Anscombe emphasized importance visualizing data prior calculating summary statistics. Dataset 1 linear relationship x y Dataset 2 shows nonlinear relationship x y Dataset 3 linear relationship x y single outlier Dataset 4 shows relationship x y single outlier serves high-leverage point. datasets following statistical summaries hold: mean x: 9 variance x: 11 mean y: 7.5 variance y: 4.125 correlation x y: 0.816 linear regression x y: y = 3 + 0.5x R2 regression: 0.67

title: Datasets to Help Teach Statistics
code: library(tidyverse) library(quartets)  ggplot(anscombe_quartet, aes(x = x, y = y)) +   geom_point() +    geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = "y ~ x") +   facet_wrap(~dataset) anscombe_quartet |>   group_by(dataset) |>   summarise(mean_x = mean(x),             var_x = var(x),             mean_y = mean(y),             var_y = var(y),             cor = cor(x, y)) |>   knitr::kable(digits = 2)

title: Datasets to Help Teach Statistics
text: goal causal_quartet data set help drive home point presented exposure, outcome, measured factors, statistics alone, whether summary statistics data visualizations, sufficient determine appropriate causal estimate. Additional information data generating mechanism needed order draw correct conclusions. See paper details.

title: Datasets to Help Teach Statistics
code: ggplot(causal_quartet, aes(x = exposure, y = outcome)) +   geom_point() +    geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = "y ~ x") +   facet_wrap(~dataset) causal_quartet |>   nest_by(dataset) |>   mutate(`Y ~ X` = round(coef(lm(outcome ~ exposure, data = data))[2], 2),          `Y ~ X + Z` = round(coef(lm(outcome ~ exposure + covariate, data = data))[2], 2),          `Correlation of X and Z` = round(cor(data$exposure, data$covariate), 2)) |>   select(-data, `Data generating mechanism` = dataset) |>   knitr::kable()

title: Datasets to Help Teach Statistics

title: Datasets to Help Teach Statistics
text: set 3 datasets demonstrating slopes estimated simple linear interaction model may , underlying data-generating mechanisms can vastly different.
code: ggplot(interaction_triptych, aes(x, y)) +   geom_point(shape = "o") +   geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = "y ~ x") +    facet_grid(dataset ~ moderator)

title: Datasets to Help Teach Statistics
text: dataset demonstrates model diagnostics alone (R2 RMSE) tell full story prediction model. , three predictors one outcome. Models fit using regression tree, linear regression, random forest, neural network yield R2 RMSE, finding different relationships predictors, evidenced partial dependence plots. can see models “perform” . way fit actual predictors quite different:
code: set.seed(1568) library(tidymodels) library(DALEXtra) rec <- recipe(y ~ ., data = rashomon_quartet_train)  ## Regression Tree  wf_tree <- workflow() |>   add_recipe(rec) |>   add_model(     decision_tree(mode = "regression", engine = "rpart",                   tree_depth = 3, min_n = 250)   )  tree <- fit(wf_tree, rashomon_quartet_train) exp_tree <- explain_tidymodels(   tree,    data = rashomon_quartet_test[, -1],    y = rashomon_quartet_test[, 1],   verbose = FALSE,    label = "decision tree")  ## Linear Model  wf_linear <- wf_tree |>   update_model(linear_reg())  lin <- fit(wf_linear, rashomon_quartet_train) exp_lin <- explain_tidymodels(   lin,    data = rashomon_quartet_test[, -1],    y = rashomon_quartet_test[, 1],   verbose = FALSE,    label = "linear regression")  ## Random Forest  wf_rf <- wf_tree |>   update_model(rand_forest(mode = "regression",                             engine = "randomForest",                             trees = 100))  rf <- fit(wf_rf, rashomon_quartet_train) exp_rf <- explain_tidymodels(   rf,    data = rashomon_quartet_test[, -1],    y = rashomon_quartet_test[, 1],   verbose = FALSE,    label = "random forest")  ## Neural Network  library(neuralnet) nn <- neuralnet(   y ~ .,    data = rashomon_quartet_train,    hidden = c(8, 4),    threshold = 0.05)  exp_nn <- explain_tidymodels(   nn,    data = rashomon_quartet_test[, -1],    y = rashomon_quartet_test[, 1],   verbose = FALSE,    label = "neural network") mp <- map(list(exp_tree, exp_lin, exp_rf, exp_nn), model_performance) tibble(   model = c("Decision tree", "Linear regression", "Random forest", "Neural network"),   R2 = map_dbl(mp, ~.x$measures$r2),   RMSE = map_dbl(mp, ~.x$measures$rmse)   ) |>   knitr::kable(digits = 2) pd_tree <- model_profile(exp_tree, N=NULL) pd_lin <- model_profile(exp_lin, N=NULL) pd_rf <- model_profile(exp_rf, N=NULL) pd_nn <- model_profile(exp_nn, N=NULL) plot(pd_tree, pd_nn, pd_rf, pd_lin)

what: Gelman Variation and Heterogeneity Causal Quartets
title: Datasets to Help Teach Statistics
text: first set data variation_causal_quartet demonstrates can get average treatment effect despite variability across pre-treatment characteristic (called z).  heterogeneous_causal_quartet demonstrates can observe causal effect different patterns treatment heterogeneity.
code: ggplot(variation_causal_quartet, aes(x = covariate, y = outcome, color = factor(exposure))) +    geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +    facet_wrap(~ dataset) +    labs(color = "exposure group") variation_causal_quartet |>   nest_by(dataset) |>   mutate(ATE = round(coef(lm(outcome ~ exposure, data = data))[2], 2)) |>   select(-data, dataset) |>   knitr::kable() ggplot(heterogeneous_causal_quartet, aes(x = covariate, y = outcome, color = factor(exposure))) +    geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +    facet_wrap(~ dataset) +    labs(color = "exposure group") heterogeneous_causal_quartet |>   nest_by(dataset) |>   mutate(ATE = round(coef(lm(outcome ~ exposure, data = data))[2], 2)) |>   select(-data, dataset) |>   knitr::kable()

title: Time-varying Causal Quartet Data — causal_collider_time
text: causal_collider_time: dataframe 100 rows 7 variables: covariate_baseline: known factor measured baseline exposure_baseline: exposure measured baseline outcome_baseline: outcome measured baseline exposure_followup: exposure measured followup visit (final time) outcome_followup: outcome measured followup visit (final time) covariate_followup: known factor measured followup visit (final time) causal_confounding_time: dataframe 100 rows 7 variables: covariate_baseline: known factor measured baseline exposure_baseline: exposure measured baseline outcome_baseline: outcome measured baseline exposure_followup: exposure measured followup visit (final time) outcome_followup: outcome measured followup visit (final time) covariate_followup: known factor measured followup visit (final time) causal_mediator_time: dataframe 100 rows 7 variables: covariate_baseline: known factor measured baseline exposure_baseline: exposure measured baseline outcome_baseline: outcome measured baseline covariate_mid: known factor measured mid-point exposure_mid: exposure measured mid-point outcome_mid: outcome measured mid-point exposure_followup: exposure measured followup visit (final time) outcome_followup: outcome measured followup visit (final time) covariate_followup: known factor measured followup visit (final time) causal_m_bias_time: dataframe 100 rows 9 variables: u1: unmeasured factor u2: unmeasured factor covariate_baseline: known factor measured baseline exposure_baseline: exposure measured baseline outcome_baseline: outcome measured baseline exposure_followup: exposure measured followup visit (final time) outcome_followup: outcome measured followup visit (final time) covariate_followup: known factor measured followup visit (final time) object class tbl_df (inherits tbl, data.frame) 400 rows 12 columns.

title: Time-varying Causal Quartet Data — causal_collider_time
text: two time points: baseline follow datasets help demonstrate model includes pre-exposure covariates (, adjusting covariates measured baseline), less prone potential biases. Adjusting pre-exposure covariates "solves" bias datasets 1-3. solve data generated "M-bias" scenario, however toy example, shown many times assumptions needed M-bias hold often ones practically see data analysis.

title: Time-varying Causal Quartet Data — causal_collider_time
text: D'Agostino McGowan L, Barrett M (2023). Causal inference statistical problem. Preprint arXiv:2304.02683v1.

title: Time-varying Causal Quartet Data — causal_collider_time
code: ## incorrect model because covariate is post-treatment lm(outcome_followup ~ exposure_baseline + covariate_followup,    data = causal_collider_time) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = outcome_followup ~ exposure_baseline + covariate_followup,  #>     data = causal_collider_time) #>  #> Coefficients: #>        (Intercept)   exposure_baseline  covariate_followup   #>           -0.05656             0.41288             0.46683   #>   ## correct model because covariate is pre-treatment ## even though the true mechanism dictates that the covariate is a collider, ## because the pre-exposure variable is used, the collider bias does not ## occur. lm(outcome_followup ~ exposure_baseline + covariate_baseline,    data = causal_collider_time) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = outcome_followup ~ exposure_baseline + covariate_baseline,  #>     data = causal_collider_time) #>  #> Coefficients: #>        (Intercept)   exposure_baseline  covariate_baseline   #>           -0.10534             1.00312            -0.01173   #>

title: Interaction Triptych Data — interaction_triptych

title: Interaction Triptych Data — interaction_triptych
text: dataframe 2700 rows 5 variables: dataset: ideal, floor, smaller correlation larger slope moderator: factor potentially interacts x, values: low, medium, high x y

title: Interaction Triptych Data — interaction_triptych
text: ideal scenario, slopes differ moderator level. "floor effect" scenario, illusion interaction, even though main effects simulated. third scenario, slopes increase higher moderator values correlation decreases. Running linear model allow appropriate differentiation effects. case potential moderator "low" "medium" "high" values.

title: Rashomon Quartet Data — rashomon_quartet
text: dataset contains 2,000 observations, 1,000 training observations 1,000 testing observations. generated 4 modeling techniques (regression tree, linear model, neural network, random forest) yield \(R^2\) RMSE fit models differently.

title: Rashomon Quartet Data — rashomon_quartet
text: rashomon_quartet: dataframe 2000 rows 5 variables: split: train, test x1 x2 x3 y rashomon_quartet_train: dataframe 1000 rows 4 variables: x1 x2 x3 y rashomon_quartet_test: dataframe 1000 rows 4 variables: x1 x2 x3 y

title: Rashomon Quartet Data — rashomon_quartet
text: three explanatory variables x1, x2, x3 one outcome y generated : \(y = sin((3x_1 + x_2)/5)+\varepsilon\) \(\varepsilon\sim N(0,1/3)\) \([x_1,x_2,x_3]\sim N(0, \Sigma_{3x3})\) \(\Sigma_{3x3}\) 1 diagonal 0.9 elsewhere. fit using following hyperparameters, model yield \(R^2\) 0.73 RMSE 0.354 Regression tree: max depth: 3, min split: 250 Linear model: main effects Random Forest: mtry: 1, number trees: 100 Neural network: hidden neurons layer: 8, 4, threshold partial derivatives error function stopping criteria: 0.05 rashomon_quartet_train contains just training data rashomon_quartet_test contains test data.

title: Rashomon Quartet Data — rashomon_quartet
text: P. Biecek, H. Baniecki, M. Krzyziński, D. Cook. Performance enough: story Rashomon’s quartet. Preprint arXiv:2302.13356v2, 2023.

what: Gelman Variation Causal Quartet Data — variation_causal_quartet
title: Gelman Variation Causal Quartet Data — variation_causal_quartet
text: dataset contains 88 observations, generated different mechanism variation treatment effect respect pre-exposure characteristic, z: (1) Constant effect (2) Low variation (3) High variation (4) Occasional large effects

title: Gelman Variation Causal Quartet Data — variation_causal_quartet
Gelman Variation Causal Quartet Data — variation_causal_quartet
text: dataframe 88 rows 5 variables: dataset: data generating mechanism exposure: exposure covariate: pre-exposure factor outcome: outcome .causal_effect: Latent true causal effect

title: Gelman Variation Causal Quartet Data — variation_causal_quartet
text: Gelman, ., Hullman, J., & Kennedy, L. (2023). Causal quartets: Different ways attain average treatment effect. arXiv preprint arXiv:2302.12878. Hullman J (2023). causalQuartet: Create Causal Quartets Interrogating Average Treatment Effects. R package version 0.0.0.9000.
